dek: What our bodies do for work

stand_sit.text: What portion of the day do you stand at work?

salary.text: What is your salary range? (We won’t store your information.)

story.text: This circle represents every laundry worker in America. Each inside dot represents about 50,000 Americans who do this job.
Laundry workers are Standers→—people who are required to stand most of the time at work. Here are some workers who are Standers.
On the left are ←Sitters—people who are almost always sitting at work.
Oh, and here’s you! We’ll keep track of you through this piece.
And in the middle is every other job in America. Zoom and pan to explore the chart.

This story is about two kinds of workers in America: ←Sitters—people who sit for living—and Standers→—those who stand, crouch, crawl, and lift. In the past few generations, work in America has become far [less physical](https://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/2006/03/art3full.pdf). A lot of farming and factory work was replaced by desk jobs. In turn, work became less backbreaking—and less dangerous. >>fatalities|Workplace safety since 1970|Source: US Department of Labor|Chart showing workers are injured and killed less on the job since 1970.

But our society still needs lots of people to do physical, grueling jobs. To understand who does these jobs, I analyzed a federal survey that asked workers what they are physically required to do for their job.
The [Occupational Requirements Survey](https://www.bls.gov/ors/) talked to workers at more than 56,000 workplaces. A small portion of jobs do not have data for various physical requirements, so those were left out of this visualization.
Let’s first look at ←Sitters.

story.hl: Percent of workers, choice of sitting or standing is allowed
story.text: Many Sitters have a choice to sit or stand.

story.hl: Percent of workers, minimum education level is a bachelor's degree
story.text: Sitters often have jobs that require a bachelor’s degree.

story.hl: A_MEAN
story.text: In turn, Sitters tend to have higher incomes.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required once per day
story.text: Sitters are more likely to have to solve problems every day.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with the ability to pause work
story.text: And Sitters get more autonomy. These are workers who say they can pause work when they need to.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with telework available
story.text: Sitters are also more likely to say they can work remotely. Only a tiny portion of Americans have this option.
Now let’s focus on Standers →. If you visited them at work, this is who would be standing at any given time.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required less often than monthly, including never
story.text: Standers are more likely to say they are never or rarely have to problem-solve for their job.

story.hl: Percent of workers, crouching is required
story.text: Standers are more likely to say they crouch at work—everyone from nurses to electricians.

story.hl: Percent of workers, climbing ladders, ropes, or scaffolds is required
story.text: Standers are also more likely to climb ladders, ropes, or scaffolds. This includes firefighters and janitors.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to wetness
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to wetness, like water, sewage, or bodily fluids.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to extreme heat
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to extreme heat from things like stoves and fires.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to outdoors
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to the outdoors—something that will become more and more dangerous as our planet warms.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to hazardous contaminants
story.text: And Standers are more likely to be exposed to hazardous contaminants.

story.hl: Percent of workers, without the ability to pause work
story.text: Standers often lack autonomy. These workers say they lack control over when they can take a break.

story.hl: INJURY_RATE
story.text: All of this takes a physical toll. This is how common it is for someone doing each job to be injured or ill and require time away from work.

story.hl: A_MEAN
story.text: Despite the physical toll, Standers tend to earn less money.

For most of American history, people [worked until their bodies gave out](https://www.ssa.gov/history/pdf/80chap5.pdf). In 1900, most men older than 65 still worked to be self-sufficient, including 84% of Black Americans.


>>retired|Percentage of men older than 65 who are retired|Source: The Evolution of Retirement, by Dora L. Costa|Chart showing that most men older than 65 worked in 1900. 


In 1935, President Franklin Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act, and by 1940, people who were [65 and older](https://www.ssa.gov/oact/progdata/nra.html) started receiving [monthly checks](https://www.aarp.org/retirement/social-security/info-2020/social-security-history-timeline.html). In other words, Social Security helped people to retire.
So, who are the Standers→ in the modern day?

story.hl: white_pct
story.text: Among White workers, there’s a pretty even split between Stander and Sitters.

story.hl: asian_pct
story.text: Asian workers are more likely to be Sitters. But there are some fields, like nursing, with a large percentage of Asian people.

story.hl: black_pct
story.text: Black workers are more likely to be Standers. They disproportionately occupy jobs like correctional officers and cashiers.

story.hl: hisp_pct
story.text: Hispanic workers are far more likely to be Standers, with jobs in kitchens, housekeeping, and construction.

story.hl: noncitizen_pct
story.text: One reason for that is that immigrants workers from Latin America and Mexico are more likely to be Standers, working manually demanding—and often dangerous—jobs for low pay.

When President Roosevelt signed the Social Security bill, it [excluded](https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/ssb/v70n4/v70n4p49.html) agricultural and domestic workers. This meant most nonwhite workers did not qualify.


>>excluded|Percentage of workers excluded from Social Security, by race|Source: US Social Security Administration; US Census|Chart showing most Black workers were excluded from Social Security when the bill first passed.


Since the mid-1990s, undocumented immigrants [haven’t received](https://www.everycrsreport.com/files/20161117_RL32004_1ac9e95f5f95d1df7d25727b9ed75b47fca246e4.html#_Toc515613603) Social Security benefits, even if they pay into Social Security. There is no path to citizenship for most of these people.

The history of labor in America is defined by the least privileged people doing the least desirable work—sometimes by force.


America got rich selling cotton picked by enslaved Black people. America built the Transcontinental Railroad with Chinese immigrant labor, only to ban Chinese immigration a few decades later. And America feeds itself with animals killed and processed by Black and Hispanic meatpackers.


When politicians run for office, they campaign by talking about how they once worked manual labor jobs. But with their power, they push laws that [cut worker wages](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2024/oct/23/trump-anti-worker-union-statements), [roll back workplace safety laws](https://publicintegrity.org/politics/system-failure/deaths-cutbacks-workplace-safety-inspections-osha/), and [kick people out of the country](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/11/us/politics/trump-2025-immigration-agenda.html). 


Despite what comes out of their mouth, the message is clear: To them, some people are bodies for labor, and not humans deserving dignity.

cut.text:
My parents were immigrants. And when I was a kid, they owned a dry cleaning business. It was a common path for Korean immigrants—work at a dry cleaner until you can’t, and then eventually sell it a few years after you qualify for Social Security payments.


I spent a lot of time in the back of the dry cleaners. I played inside hanger boxes with my imaginary friend; he was a lawyer because I was enamored that he talked for a living.

cut.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
cut.text:
After a few years, they sold the dry cleaning business and eventually got into the vending machine business. My dad pushed around vending machines and boxes full of food, while my mom packed muffins and sandwiches. That was also grueling work.


One day, I remember my dad was late coming home from work. I was worried sick. 


Finally, he called: His hand was stuck in a vending machine gear, and the fire department was on the way to help him get out.

cut.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
cut.text: My dad ended up being OK. In fact, a year after that incident, he was able to go back to school to continue his education. I’m so thankful he had that choice.
